level1.p: This document provides guidance on how to use the odt2daisy extension for OpenOffice.org.

level2.p: Odt2daisy is simple to install:

li.p: select "Extension Manager â¦" in the "Tools" menu
click "Add..." , and select the downloaded oxt file

level2.p: After the installation and restart, you should find the following in OpenOffice Writer:

li.p: an âExport As DAISY XMLâ button in the toolbar
an âExport As Full DAISYâ button in the toolbar
an âExport As DAISY XMLâ menu item in the âFileâ menu
an âExport As Full DAISYâ menu item in the âFileâ menu
a set of templates in the âDAISY Booksâ folder

p.sent: To export a document as DAISY XML (without audio), select âExport as DAISY XMLâ in the âFileâ menu or use the DAISY XML button on the toolbar.
TheâExport Dialogâ section describe how to fill the export dialog properly.

level1.p: A Full DAISY book contains both an audio and a text version of the content, and structure information.

p.sent: odt2daisy generates the audio version of an OpenOffice.org document by using the TTS engines or âvoicesâ installed on your operating system.
For this reason, the quality of the audio and the languages that can be produced depend on the TTS engines that are installed on your computer.

level1.p: Note: âAsianâ and âComplex Text Layoutâ (CTL) languages are not supported.

level2.p:
The English versions of Microsoft Windows (XP, Vista and 7) embed an English TTS engine,
so you can produce Full DAISY books in English out of the box.

level1.p: Note: During an export as DAISY XML, the export dialog don't include bitrate, fix routines, and sentence detection since these parameters are used for audio generation.

p.sent: The UID is a universally unique identifier for your DAISY book.
The UID is generated automatically, but you can specify your own UID if you prefer.
DAISY Book Title.
This field will be empty if you have not filled in the title of the file in the file properties.
You can also set the title of the file in the Properties dialog in the File menu in OpenOffice.org: in the Properties dialog, go to the Description tab and fill in the Title field.
The author of the DAISY book.
This field is filled automatically with user data from OpenOffice.org.

If the field is empty and you want it to be automatically filled with your name, you can also set your first name and last name in the Options dialog under the Tools menu: go to âUser dataâ (in the OpenOffice.org section of the options) and fill in your first name and/or last name.
The agency responsible for making the DAISY book available.
Odt2daisy uses the value in Creator as default value.
The organization that created the DAISY book.
Odt2daisy uses the value in Creator as default value.

level2.p: The main language of the document must be set in Tools > Language > For all Text... > Language .

p.sent: Odt2daisy can produce multilingual books.

If the document contains paragraphs in a language that is different from the default language, you should set the language of that paragraph by using Tools > Language > For Paragraph.
If the document contains words or phrases in a language that is different from the immediately surrounding text, you should set the language of that word or phrase by using Tools > Language > For Selection.
If your document contains page numbers, you can choose to include them in your DAISY book.
If you check the box âinclude page numbersâ, all pages that have a footer or a header with a âPage Number fieldâ will have page number in DAISY.

level3.p: If your document does not contain page numbers, you add them by following these steps:

p.sent: Go to Insert > Footer (or Header) > Default.
This adds an empty footer (or header) section to your document.

li.p: Go to Insert > Fields > Page Number.
You can change the alignment of the page number in the Paragraph dialogue under the Format menu or by using the alignment buttons on the toolbar.

level3.p: Odt2daisy allows several pages to be numbered as a single page in the DAISY book.
If you want to output two or more pages in OpenOffice.org as a single DAISY page, proceed as follows:

li.p: Create a new Page Style, named âNoPageNumberâ (or any other name you find more appropriate) without any Page Number in header or footer.
Write the first page with a page style including a Page Number in header or footer, for example page number 3
Write the other pages using the page style named âNoPageNumberâ
At the last page, insert a page break, change style to a Page Numbered Style, and change the page number to what would be the next page number, in this example page 4.

level2.p: If you check âuse alternate level markupâ, your DAISY book will use <level depth=''N''> notation instead of <levelN>.
It must be checked if your book use âHeading 7â Style and higher.
If you check âinclude CSSâ, odt2daisy will also produce a CSS file.
This CSS file allows to view your DAISY book in a browser.

p.sent: Selects the bit rate of the generated MP3 audio files.
A higher value will result in better sound quality but the audio files will be larger.
The default value is 32 kbit/s.
Selects whether to apply DAISY book fix routines to the input document.
These routines try to clean and possibly repair the input DAISY XML document to enforce the best compatibility with the remaining steps.
This option is recommended.

level2.p: Selects whether to apply sentence detection to the input document text to enable a finer-grained audio synchronization.

level1.p: If you conversion error occurs during the export process, odt2daisy will show a warning.

img.alt: Screenshot of OpenOffice.org showing odt2daisy error dialog

imggroup.caption: Illustration 5: Example of an error: an heading 1 followed by an heading 3

p.sent: It is important to fix any errors in the source document before exporting the DAISY book.
It is highly discouraged to use or distribute an invalid DAISY Book.
A common cause of errors is the incorrect use of heading levels, for example if the first heading after a Heading 1 is a Heading 3 instead of a Heading 2, the resulting DAISY book will not be valid.

level1.p:
DAISY format is âstructure centeredâ so your OpenOffice.org document have to be well structured.
Please respect accessibility rules for a better document.
You should start to check these points before going further during an export as DAISY error or simply for produce more accessible DAISY books:

li.p:
Check the Heading structure of your document using the OpenOffice.org Navigator
(View > Navigator > Headings)
Avoid gaps (Heading 1 followed by an Heading 3)

Search hidden structure issues by showing Non printing characters
(âViewâ > âNonprinting Charactersâ)
keep in mind that a new paragraph (key âEnterâ) is different than a break line (keys âShift + Enterâ)
with headings (âInsertâ > âTable...â and check heading)
avoid nested tables (A table included in another one)
Use JPEG, PNG or SVG pictures only

p.sent: Fill alternative text.
It should be relevant and must be different if you have a caption.

li.p: Picture: right click > âPicture...â then select the âOptionsâ tab and fill âAlternative (Text only)â field.
Formula: right click > âObject...â then select the âOptionsâ tab and fill âAlternative (Text only)â field.

p.sent: Fill language of each part of your document (selection, paragraph and all text).
This step is crucial for âExport as DAISYâ during audio generation

li.p:
start by setting the main language of the document
(Tools > Language > For all Text)

set every words or any selection of the document with a different language
(Tools > Language > For Selection)

set every paragraphs of the document with a different language
(Tools > Language > For Paragraph)
Use OpenOffice.org styles for formatting your document
Use DAISY styles (name start with â[DAISY]â) to enrich the structure

p.sent: The instructions in the first part of this manual explain how to produce simple DAISY books.
The next part of the manual provides information for people who want to create DAISY from more complex documents, or who want to use more complex DAISY features.

level2.p:
Subject and Keywords metadata can be set in File > Properties > Description.
Keywords must be separated by a comma.

level3.p:
The front matter is automatically managed by the translator.
It will include everything before the first âHeading 1â inside a <level1 class=''title_page''>.

You can specify the front matter with a Section named âBodyMatterStartâ.
In that case, the front matter will be everything before this section.
Note: âAdvanced DAISY Bookâ template can be a good start.

Rear matter can be defined with a Section named âRearMatterStartâ.
In that case, rear matter start after it.
Note: âAdvanced DAISY Bookâ template can be a good start.

level2.p:
Levels are mapped with Heading 1, Heading 2, â¦, Heading X Styles.
You should have a correct Heading markup to produce a DAISY book.
This means you cannot have a Heading 3 just after an Heading 1, for example.

You can produce levels with Part, Chapter, Sections and Subsection class attributes.
For example, if your level1 is a âPartâ , specify it like this:

li.p: go to File > Properties > User Defined
click on âInfo fields...â and change âInfo 1â to âDAISY TOP LEVELâ
put âPartâ as value (others values are âChapterâ and âSectionâ)

p.sent: âPartâ value will map level1 to part, level2 to chapter, level3 to section, level4 to subsection.
âChapterâ value will map level1 to chapter, level2 to section, level3 to subsection.
âSectionâ value will map level1 to section, level2 to subsection.

p.span: Note: âPart DAISY Bookâ, âChapter DAISY Bookâ and âSection DAISYBookâ templates can be a good start.

level2.p: Bold, Italic, Emphasis Style, Strong Emphasis Style, Subscript and Superscript, Emails and Hyperlinks are natively supported, so they can be used as usual.

level3.p: Anchors can be produced using a bookmark (Insert > Bookmark, Insert > Cross Reference)

You can also load the DAISY Style using the âFormatting and Styles dialogâ.

Images are supported natively, you can insert it with: Insert > Picture > from File...

level2.p:
Images without a text alternative are not accessible If an image is not purely decorative, you should provide Alternate Text using
âRight Clickâ > Picture â¦ > Options > Alternative (text only)
Captions are also supported using âRight Clickâ > Caption â¦ > Caption field.

Mathematics are supported natively, you can insert a formula with: Insert > Object... > Formula.
You should also provide a âtextualâ version of the formula using âRight Clickâ > âObject...â > Alternative (text only)
Notes, Footnotes and Endnotes are supported natively, so you can use them as usual.

For example, this section:

Frames are natively supported, so you can use them as usual.

h2.a: Why odt2daisy works only with OpenOffice.org 3.0 (or grather) ?

level2.p: Odt2daisy works only with OOo.org 3.0 because it's compatible with ODF 1.2 (or grather).

h2.a: Why odt2daisy doesn't detect the right document language ?

level2.p:
You need to set the right document language like this in OOO.org with
"Tools" > "Language" > "For All Text" > YOUR LANGUAGE

h2.a: Why my DAISY book have not pagenum tag ?

p.sent: Odt2daisy output a pagenum if only a header or a footer is in the page and have a Page Number Field.

You can do it like this:
"Insert" > "Footer" > "Default", and next "Insert" > "Fields" > "Page Number"

h2.a: Why the error "Could not create Java implementation loader" occurs during installation ?

level2.p:
This error occurs if you didn't install or configure Java JRE properly.
Go to "Tools" > "Options ..." then select "Java" in the list and verify:

li.p: Use a Java runtime environment should be checked
A JRE should be selected in "Java runtime environment (JRE) already installed" list

level2.p: If this list is empty, you should install a JRE at Java SE Downloads page.

h2.a: Why the error "(com.sun.star.registry.CannotRegisterImplementationException) { { Message = "", Context = com.sun.star.unoXInterface) @0 } }

p.sent: This error can occurs on some operating systems which doesn't include a proper version of OpenOffice.org.
You should remove OpenOffice.org and install a new version from official website.
